content: x 1 5 = 6 + 5 - 6 = 5 therefore the hood width is 5 squares the hood height needs to be at least half the hood measurement bigger is better work out the hood measurement divided by the square size and divide by two then round up to the next integer this is the hood height hood measurement / square size / 2 rounded up to the next integer e g 23/4 / 2 = 5 75/ 2 = 2 875 therefore the hood height is 3 squares hood width x hood height = hood squares e g 5 x 3 is 15 squares pockets it is entirely up to you how many pockets you have and how big you make them my pockets are each 2 squares high and 1 square wide and i have one pocket on each side i used 4 squares total for my pockets total squares estimate add up all the squares you will need for each panel you will need ● 1 back panel ● 2 front panels ● 2 sleeves ● 1 hood ● pockets as desired my cardigan has ● 30 squares in the back panel ● 18 squares in each front panel ● 16 squares in each sleeve ● 15 squares in the hood ● 4 squares for pockets 30 + 18 + 18 + 16 + 16 + 15 + 4 = 117 squares page 6 recipe for a granny square cardigan by insertinnergeek designs step 4 start making squares now you know approximately how many squares you will need time to get crocheting step 5 fit check when you have made about half your squares it is probably a good time to pause and check the fit this can be affected by how stretchy your squares are and how you would like the cardigan to fit so it is worth double checking at some point you will be checking ● sleeve circumference ● sleeve length ● back panel width ● front panel width ● front panel length ● hood height doubled join a row of squares equal to the smallest of these and you can add squares to the row as you go to check the longer parts see step 6 joining the squares 1 1 it is a good idea to use the joining method that you will use for the final cardigan but it isn t the end of the world if you change your mind later page 7 recipe for a granny square cardigan by insertinnergeek designs sleeve circumference you can use this row to check that the sleeve will fit comfortably around the arm sleeve length check that the sleeve length is ok bearing in mind that it will start a little below the shoulder when the cardigan is sewn up and a cuff will be added to the end back panel width check that with a small amount of pressure to mimic the weight of the finished
